The Trustees of the Middletown Academy have
seen anonymous attack upon them in the Della.
ware Gazettec of the 29th ult. signed " voter"


A sense of duty to themselves and the public In
duces them to give an indignant denial to the base
conduct and motives imputed to them.

Quoted, in this place, by the Inspector and Judges,
has been so palpaby opposite to fair dealing, that


think 1t not right to let it pass unnoticed. Hereto
lore 1t has been the constant custom OF the nspec-
tor to appoint one Judge from each party, thereby
giving to each an opportunity of making their obec-
ions TO any person Of whatever party he might be:
But how has it been in the late instance So far
from considering himself bound by the uniformly es-
tabshed principle Of honor observed all such oc-
casons heretofore, that both Judges were selected
from the Jackson ranks: and this will be consider
ed more disgracetu, when it is recollected that the
Assessor and Collectors, who also entitled I'd be-
In the room, and whose testimony would have some
influence in the decision respecting vote, were
also Jackson men-this being announced previous to
the election, the friends of the Administration pre-
pared themselves, to meet this unfair arrangement
as far as lay in their power, by challenging outside
the window such votes they knew to be illegal
and in some Of the most garing instances succeeded
in defeating the intention which appeared to be
with those in authority, Jackson ragM wrong-
Whatever may have induced the course taken, am
perfectly satisfied that all honorable men, jackson
or Adams, will condemn it i by it believe, the adj
ministraon party have lost many votes, as legal as
any given in, and the jackson party have an acces
sion of many, believed to be illegal: in some of
which latter instances the preference shown by the
Inspector was so glaring as to draw forth express





of whom admit that the good old rule g to work
both ways" did not apply with the cordial consent
of Inspector and Judges This assures us that what
ever votes the Administration have received are
such, as did not admit of a doubt--One or two Of
the cases that occurred at the window worthy Of
nctice--A person who has long voted, presented
us ticket at the window several times, and was
fused vote, OH the ground of want OF evidence of
citizenship he then produced paper bearing the
LAl.1
prove that right This was also refused, and the
vote would probably have been lost had it not been
for the perseverance of his friends one at least of
whom accompanied him to the office OF one Of our
most eminent legal characters, who, although
Jackson man, pronounced the evidence before Of
ered to the Inspector, such to entitle the ndi-
ydual to vote he then repaired for sixth time
to the polls. accompanied by jackson and Adams
man, each of whom had accompanied HIM to take
council, and his vote was then received. This
transaction is worthy of being borne in mind by all
those possessed of honorable feelings, to whatever
party they may belong: for it the plea of ignorance
is put in by the Inspector it ought at least to con-
vince us of the propriety Of selecting such as
| competent for thatimportant station. By so doing
all the difficulty that occurred, arising out of want
of confidence, on this, might be avoided on any SUBJ
sequen occason For let it be remembered, that if
both parties have not the most entire confidence in



trust, great excitement must be the consequence
Another instance occurred. Of person whose right
to vote in the county was notdisputed, but who was
refused vote on the ground of residence in anoth-
er hundred proof was offered that he was at the
time resident in this hundred, still he was refused
and was finally obliged either to ride ten miles to
and from the adjoining hundred and bring a cer6-
cate that he not entitled to vote there or lose
his vote in this. By those who witnessed most of
Al,
will not be admitted, other cases of such an ag-
gravated nature occurred, as to stamp their inten-
tions with the most doubtful character If, fellow
citizens, such measures resorted to, to secure
the election of the General, for one, have yet too
good opinion of the state of honorable feeling that
obtains among us, to believe, that it will not re-ac:
by exposing the deformity of the cause is intend
ed to support OBSERVER.
/ For the Delaware Journal


One of the most remarkable instances OF the
blindness of prejudice and party zeal, and their
power to over rule the Judgment, occurred short
time since in Mill Greek Hundred, where, one Of
the most respectable citizens gave it his opinion,
either that there not, or that he knew Of but
nine Administration votes in that Kindred Now
am willing to say, from the general good charac
ter of this man, that believe he thought so at thu
time, that he would not any occasion assert pal
pable untruth. TO what cause, then, must we lool
for such an opinion, held by individual, who. un
tramelled by party zeal, had every opportunity o
knowing the political sentiments Of his hundred


certainly of nothing else than the disqualifying et


ects of violent party zeal and prejudice of the un
happy influence of which we have so many instan
ces, in which it extends beyond the open field O.
political controversy, and sewers the most intimate
personal friendships The recent result of thu
election in that hundred. if am correctly informed
] has been 22l for jackson, and SO for the Admus
of only 6t
For the Delaware Journal.

TO the Editor of the Dciaooare Journal.
COLUMBIA. (Pa.) Sept. 80, 1897.
| Dear STRENGTHENING that it is important for the
good cause in which we embarked that correct


information respecting the and state of the
administration party here, should be known abroad,
send you the proceedings of a meeting held n this
place short time ago. which proved TO consist of
majority in numbers and intelligence of the citizens
here and further as a proof of what is doing in
Pennsylvania, particularly in Lancaster County,
which has heretofore been considered the hot-bed
|of the Opposition in this State. AT our election for
Township officers, Inspector and Assessor) which
was made question Adams or Jackson, and was con-
sdered far trial of strength, the friends of the
administration gained the election by 81 votes of a
majority, and the same result occurred in many
other townships where the Election was made a
|question between the two parties.


At a large and respectable meeting of the
citizens of Columbia and vicinity, friendly to the
reelection of John Quincy Adams, as the Presi-
dent OF the United States, convened at the house
OF George Peters on Monday evening the 18th
September l827 the meeting called to the chair Dr.
RICHARD e. COCHRAN, and appointed George
c. Lloyd, and Peter Hald,naa, Secretaries.
The object of the meeting being stated bv the
chairman, on motion, committee of five persons
appointed to draught resolutions expressive of
the sense OF the meeting The committee after


having retired for short time reported the follow


ing resolutions. which were separately read, and


unanimously agreed to.


| Resolved, That this meeting have the highest


confidence IN the present Administration of the Cen


eral Government, and from conviction of the great


talents and unmpeachable integrity of John Quincy
Adams, who has possessed the confidence of every


President of the United States, evinced by his ap-


pontment to many ofthe highest and most important


civil stations, both foreign and domestic, by Wash


ington, Jefferson, Madison, and Monroe the duties


of which he has discharged with honour to himself


and credit and usefulness to his country we deem it


our duty, and hereby pledge ourselves to use all


fair and honourable means to promote his re-elec-
ton to the Presidency.


Resolved, That we view with regret and astonish-
lment, the vile sanders that certain disappointed


and evil minded men, have attempted to heap upon


our viruous and distinguished fellow citizen Henry
lClay and at the same time that rejoice to find
them unable to prove single CHARGE we deem it the
lduty OF every good citizen to rown Indignantly upon
levery attempt to inure the character of this bene
factor of his country.


Resolved, That we will by all proper means en-
ldeavour to prevent the election of General Jackson
lbeng convinced OF his total incapacty to fill the
ldigniied station of President to which he aspres
land for which such unjust and unwarrantable means


Ihave been taken.


Resolved, That it is the opinion Of this meeting
THAT General County meeting should be called a


as early day as it will be possible to notify tht


friends OF the Administration throughout this county


I hat of ndanc


lot live persons, be appointed, who shall have powe


to call meetings at such times and places as the,
il think proper for the promotion of the good cause il
e which embarked


l. Resolved, That DR.. Richard f. Cochran, Georg
is Z. Lloyd Christian Benneman, Evan Green, ant
e Moses Montgomery, be that Committee.
l. Resolved That the proceedings of this meetin
" be published in all the papers printed in the cit
e of Lancaster, and in the papers friendly to the AID
e mnisration tthe General Government inPhiladel
It phia and elsewhere:


l. RICHARD f. COCHRAN, Chairman.
s. GEORGE G. LoYp, lsecretar;as
a. PETER HELDEMAN, (
in 1t having been scarcely three weeks since th
J. friends Of the Administration in this place began
act in concert and form themselves into the party
~ renders the prospect quite ilatterng for fin;
ii success for when we take into view the fact th:
IN there has not been single newspaper in the count
h friendly to the Administration and the Jackson print
have been circulating their sanders against the Ger
We eral Government for the proceeding two years an
r. an half without contradictions it would not be SUI
a prisng to see them have large majority over us
nd and not in the least expected that we should be ab
n 10 collect half so many votes as they.
81 A county meeting was called in Lancaster Q
of Saturday last of the friends of the Administration
ch which was very respectfully attended an atldre

All the influence which our politicians Of tile Or
position in Delaware could exert.-(and it was vari.
Gus and exerted to the utmost extenD could not de-
feat the election of Mr. Johns. The people are
often very troublesome to manage, especially when
they know thing or two and as the time is near
at hand when their knowledge will become more ex-
tenslve, SO will the number of the friends of order
and good government vastly multiply.


Notwithstanding, reader. you may expect to hear
as you have heard thousand other things that Del
aware is still for General Jacksoni!!
DELAWARE JOURNaL.

W.Iaal..I,lN alr1Ns

A GOOD BEGINNING.

election, several hundred votes in the city.

"a few more or less:

full articles.headline: For the Delaware Journal.
full articles.article:
Quoted, in this place, by the Inspector and Judges,
has been so palpaby opposite to fair dealing, that


think 1t not right to let it pass unnoticed. Hereto
lore 1t has been the constant custom OF the nspec-
tor to appoint one Judge from each party, thereby
giving to each an opportunity of making their obec-
ions TO any person Of whatever party he might be:
But how has it been in the late instance So far
from considering himself bound by the uniformly es-
tabshed principle Of honor observed all such oc-
casons heretofore, that both Judges were selected
from the Jackson ranks: and this will be consider
ed more disgracetu, when it is recollected that the
Assessor and Collectors, who also entitled I'd be-
In the room, and whose testimony would have some
influence in the decision respecting vote, were
also Jackson men-this being announced previous to
the election, the friends of the Administration pre-
pared themselves, to meet this unfair arrangement
as far as lay in their power, by challenging outside
the window such votes they knew to be illegal
and in some Of the most garing instances succeeded
in defeating the intention which appeared to be
with those in authority, Jackson ragM wrong-
Whatever may have induced the course taken, am
perfectly satisfied that all honorable men, jackson
or Adams, will condemn it i by it believe, the adj
ministraon party have lost many votes, as legal as
any given in, and the jackson party have an acces
sion of many, believed to be illegal: in some of
which latter instances the preference shown by the
Inspector was so glaring as to draw forth express





of whom admit that the good old rule g to work
both ways" did not apply with the cordial consent
of Inspector and Judges This assures us that what
ever votes the Administration have received are
such, as did not admit of a doubt--One or two Of
the cases that occurred at the window worthy Of
nctice--A person who has long voted, presented
us ticket at the window several times, and was
fused vote, OH the ground of want OF evidence of
citizenship he then produced paper bearing the
LAl.1
prove that right This was also refused, and the
vote would probably have been lost had it not been
for the perseverance of his friends one at least of
whom accompanied him to the office OF one Of our
most eminent legal characters, who, although
Jackson man, pronounced the evidence before Of
ered to the Inspector, such to entitle the ndi-
ydual to vote he then repaired for sixth time
to the polls. accompanied by jackson and Adams
man, each of whom had accompanied HIM to take
council, and his vote was then received. This
transaction is worthy of being borne in mind by all
those possessed of honorable feelings, to whatever
party they may belong: for it the plea of ignorance
is put in by the Inspector it ought at least to con-
vince us of the propriety Of selecting such as
| competent for thatimportant station. By so doing
all the difficulty that occurred, arising out of want
of confidence, on this, might be avoided on any SUBJ
sequen occason For let it be remembered, that if
both parties have not the most entire confidence in



trust, great excitement must be the consequence
Another instance occurred. Of person whose right
to vote in the county was notdisputed, but who was
refused vote on the ground of residence in anoth-
er hundred proof was offered that he was at the
time resident in this hundred, still he was refused
and was finally obliged either to ride ten miles to
and from the adjoining hundred and bring a cer6-
cate that he not entitled to vote there or lose
his vote in this. By those who witnessed most of
Al,
will not be admitted, other cases of such an ag-
gravated nature occurred, as to stamp their inten-
tions with the most doubtful character If, fellow
citizens, such measures resorted to, to secure
the election of the General, for one, have yet too
good opinion of the state of honorable feeling that
obtains among us, to believe, that it will not re-ac:
by exposing the deformity of the cause is intend
ed to support OBSERVER.
/ For the Delaware Journal


One of the most remarkable instances OF the
blindness of prejudice and party zeal, and their
power to over rule the Judgment, occurred short
time since in Mill Greek Hundred, where, one Of
the most respectable citizens gave it his opinion,
either that there not, or that he knew Of but
nine Administration votes in that Kindred Now
am willing to say, from the general good charac
ter of this man, that believe he thought so at thu
time, that he would not any occasion assert pal
pable untruth. TO what cause, then, must we lool
for such an opinion, held by individual, who. un
tramelled by party zeal, had every opportunity o
knowing the political sentiments Of his hundred


certainly of nothing else than the disqualifying et


ects of violent party zeal and prejudice of the un
happy influence of which we have so many instan
ces, in which it extends beyond the open field O.
political controversy, and sewers the most intimate
personal friendships The recent result of thu
election in that hundred. if am correctly informed
] has been 22l for jackson, and SO for the Admus
of only 6t

TO the Editor of the Dciaooare Journal.
COLUMBIA. (Pa.) Sept. 80, 1897.
| Dear STRENGTHENING that it is important for the
good cause in which we embarked that correct


information respecting the and state of the
administration party here, should be known abroad,
send you the proceedings of a meeting held n this
place short time ago. which proved TO consist of
majority in numbers and intelligence of the citizens
here and further as a proof of what is doing in
Pennsylvania, particularly in Lancaster County,
which has heretofore been considered the hot-bed
|of the Opposition in this State. AT our election for
Township officers, Inspector and Assessor) which
was made question Adams or Jackson, and was con-
sdered far trial of strength, the friends of the
administration gained the election by 81 votes of a
majority, and the same result occurred in many
other townships where the Election was made a
|question between the two parties.


At a large and respectable meeting of the
citizens of Columbia and vicinity, friendly to the
reelection of John Quincy Adams, as the Presi-
dent OF the United States, convened at the house
OF George Peters on Monday evening the 18th
September l827 the meeting called to the chair Dr.
RICHARD e. COCHRAN, and appointed George
c. Lloyd, and Peter Hald,naa, Secretaries.
The object of the meeting being stated bv the
chairman, on motion, committee of five persons
appointed to draught resolutions expressive of
the sense OF the meeting The committee after


having retired for short time reported the follow


ing resolutions. which were separately read, and


unanimously agreed to.


| Resolved, That this meeting have the highest


confidence IN the present Administration of the Cen


eral Government, and from conviction of the great


talents and unmpeachable integrity of John Quincy
Adams, who has possessed the confidence of every


President of the United States, evinced by his ap-


pontment to many ofthe highest and most important


civil stations, both foreign and domestic, by Wash


ington, Jefferson, Madison, and Monroe the duties


of which he has discharged with honour to himself


and credit and usefulness to his country we deem it


our duty, and hereby pledge ourselves to use all


fair and honourable means to promote his re-elec-
ton to the Presidency.


Resolved, That we view with regret and astonish-
lment, the vile sanders that certain disappointed


and evil minded men, have attempted to heap upon


our viruous and distinguished fellow citizen Henry
lClay and at the same time that rejoice to find
them unable to prove single CHARGE we deem it the
lduty OF every good citizen to rown Indignantly upon
levery attempt to inure the character of this bene
factor of his country.


Resolved, That we will by all proper means en-
ldeavour to prevent the election of General Jackson
lbeng convinced OF his total incapacty to fill the
ldigniied station of President to which he aspres
land for which such unjust and unwarrantable means


Ihave been taken.


Resolved, That it is the opinion Of this meeting
THAT General County meeting should be called a


as early day as it will be possible to notify tht


friends OF the Administration throughout this county


I hat of ndanc


lot live persons, be appointed, who shall have powe


to call meetings at such times and places as the,
il think proper for the promotion of the good cause il
e which embarked


l. Resolved, That DR.. Richard f. Cochran, Georg
is Z. Lloyd Christian Benneman, Evan Green, ant
e Moses Montgomery, be that Committee.
l. Resolved That the proceedings of this meetin
" be published in all the papers printed in the cit
e of Lancaster, and in the papers friendly to the AID
e mnisration tthe General Government inPhiladel
It phia and elsewhere:


l. RICHARD f. COCHRAN, Chairman.
s. GEORGE G. LoYp, lsecretar;as
a. PETER HELDEMAN, (
in 1t having been scarcely three weeks since th
J. friends Of the Administration in this place began
act in concert and form themselves into the party
~ renders the prospect quite ilatterng for fin;
ii success for when we take into view the fact th:
IN there has not been single newspaper in the count
h friendly to the Administration and the Jackson print
have been circulating their sanders against the Ger
We eral Government for the proceeding two years an
r. an half without contradictions it would not be SUI
a prisng to see them have large majority over us
nd and not in the least expected that we should be ab
n 10 collect half so many votes as they.

of Saturday last of the friends of the Administration
ch which was very respectfully attended an atldre

DELAWARE JOURNaL.

W.Iaal..I,lN alr1Ns
EriAay, October 5, AS21.

A GOOD BEGINNING.
full articles.article:
All the influence which our politicians Of tile Or
position in Delaware could exert.-(and it was vari.
Gus and exerted to the utmost extenD could not de-
feat the election of Mr. Johns. The people are
often very troublesome to manage, especially when
they know thing or two and as the time is near
at hand when their knowledge will become more ex-
tenslve, SO will the number of the friends of order
and good government vastly multiply.


Notwithstanding, reader. you may expect to hear
as you have heard thousand other things that Del
aware is still for General Jacksoni!!

The Baltimore Electoral District, which includes
Ann Arundel County; is notD ascertaned to be IN
favor OF the Administration, in consequence of the
Administration party having gained, at the late
election, several hundred votes in the city.
